revised_title: Nerve Crossing and Restoration of Co-ordinated Movements
tldr: The author conducted experiments on dogs to understand the effects of nerve crossing on co-ordinated movements. They found that after crossing the nerve supply of flexor and extensor muscles, the animals regained the power of performing voluntary co-ordinated movements. The study also showed that the cerebral cortical centres can interchange their positions and retain their irritability after nerve crossing. Additionally, the author successfully treated a patient's facial spasm by grafting the facial nerve onto the spinal accessory nerve.
